lexUnit.name: desperation.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a state of despair, especially as resulting in rash or extreme behaviour

sentence.text: Was this the dreaded writer 's block , or was it merely her desperation to win the SHE/Timotei writing competition that had rendered her completely lost for words ?
I knew of young people who would rush into marriages , even parenthood , in order to further their passport and visa applications , such was their desperation to get out .
Her desperation to flee seemed faintly ridiculous now , but she stiffened her failing resolve with the reminder that he had tracked her to Glenshee , giving her no say whatsoever in the matter .
There was almost a desperation about the way we 'd try and fill our recreational time with something worthwhile .
He often raises that subject , and we understand his desperation about what will happen to his seat at the next election .
I share Ken Cook 's desperation at the state of the court system .
He looked at his nanny with desperation in his eyes .
Was that a note of desperation in Piper 's voice ?
The passionate desperation in his voice brought her eyes wide .
` All that mob , they 're just out to get their names in the papers and make millions off human desperation with vitamin cures .
It reveals the desperation of kids to get something from rock .
I still have it today , and I must admit that the ` poems " indicate the desperation of a lonely adolescent rather than the promise of any talent .

The surge in sales last month was also directly inspired by price cuts which reflected the desperation of many shopkeepers faced with poor results in December , traditionally the peak buying season of the year .
Mr Straw claimed that the lack of detail was a sign of the Government 's desperation .
Nina was all over him again , but more ingratiating this time , controlling her desperation , soothing the wrinkles she had put in his coat , unwrapping his scarf .
Is not the mugger a person who knows only the language of violence through which to express his desperation ?
Pop music mirrored the mood of Britain 's desperation -- and its barely expressed hopes -- in a curious way .
The idea of ` flooded classrooms " might be taken as the product of bureaucratic desperation .
I must be a virgin when I get married ! " she said shakily , begging him with a terrified desperation .
To begin with , it would have been based on absolute desperation .
More like an actress lifted to greatness by pure desperation .
Mann tries to combine the desperation of their plight with a more lyrical look at Indian respect for struggle and death , all of which sits together a smidgeon uneasily until the final reel .
Even a minor incident reveals his desperate determination to overcome , the desperation of the poor .
There is a desperation about her insistence on outward perfection .
But there was a gentle desperation in Marriage 's crooked face , and his hand crawled on the rug like a dying spider .
The husband belongs to Scarlet , a woman whose life of quiet desperation threatens to overwhelm her .
The note of quiet desperation in her friend 's voice drew Lindsey 's gaze to Jill 's flushed face , causing her own smile to fade .
With Virginia Dysart as either his ally or his dupe , only sheer desperation could have made him offer bribes to the likes of Nadine Cunningham .
The judge was reminded by her counsel that the offence was an act of sheer desperation .
He just feels the desperation of hunger that is not being dealt with .
Many of us feel a profound desperation at the global future .
In desperation he wrote for help to Europe .
She began screaming and in desperation threw ornaments and bottles .
In desperation , Nicky was sent by his parents to New York to stay with his older brother .
` We sent two volunteers in a couple of hours ago out of desperation .
